div.p:
Will you be so good to direct the
enclosed letter for me to Mr John
Gibbons. - Nobody but You that I
can hear of in this world knows
his address - The letter is in favor
of my poor niece Emmeline Gibbons
Her misfortunes and sorrow
have both meliorated her tem
per temper and strengthened her cha
racter character so that she is much more
amiable and estimable in
adversity, than she ever appeared
to me in her prosperity - She
has won - earned- - wrenched
from me my esteem: & after
my esteem flowed a certain
stream of sympathy, which
which had been stopped up - I
don't care to say how, or why. -

She has written to me two
or three excellent letters, in
which her kind, generous, &
grateful feelings charmingly
predominate - She has got her
temper under. - She now rides & runs
it - instead of letting it run away
with her, uncurbed, - &
& splashing dirt about "on each
"she doomed her foe"- -
She now is really grateful for
all kindness shown her, - and
reproaches none for want of
kindness - and does not even
expect assistance, like an Irishwo
-man Irishwoman , but hopes for it from Pro-
-vidence Providence & her fellow creatures,
like a good well-trained, thorough
-well bred English woman, or man

This being all truly so - and
not mere words, unsupported
by deeds I now my dear Dr
A proceed from my preface to
my request - I request that you
will if you can find out and get
some situation for her in which
she can earn bread (I wont ask
for butter) for her or self & her poor
little children - She is willing
to undertake any labour
and not to turn up her
start at any seeming degra
dation degradation by which she can earn
subsistence for her family
She thinks she is equal to being
housekeeper to an hospital or to
a medical Asylum or the
like or to be companion or care
taker of any old or imbecile
body or mind - She says truly
& pathetically enough that
she has had experience for the
last two years in nursing an
invalid & that respectable
medical testimonials wd
would
prove this for her -
She has some hopes (but I fear
vain) of Mrs. Stanley per favor
of petition from her governess
doing something for her in
procuring some Housekeeper
ship in the Royal house hold
or in the arrangement of the
House of Commons house-
keeper housekeeper ships - But I own
I have little hopes from Royalty
patronage there are so many
competitors for it - And fair
words are so plentiful in Royal
quarters &, you know, "fair
words butter no parsnips" - &- give
no parsnips to be buttered, - which
is worse -
I have more faith in the promise
of a certain Dr. Scott who attended
poor fretful Dr. Gibbon Gibbons
- I do not well
know who he is but I know he
has been very kind to them and
I am told that from his height in
his profession he has a true vue d'oiseau
of a great many good situations
- I wish he may pounce upon
one for my poor niece

But in my heart of hearts I
own I have more dependance
upon your friendly aid - And
quick eye for a good thing for a
friend; and my pride
My Dear Doctor Ashburner wd
be peculiarly gratified by receiv-
ing receiving from You, this assistance
"at her utmost need" for poor
Em
melene Emmelene Gibbons - I should be
proud to shew her how just my opinion
was and is of your generous
disposition, freedom from
spite, malice, or any kind of
uncharitableness - how forgiv
ing forgiving of injuries! and disdainful-
of misunderstandings, and
misinterpretations -

If you can find any situ-
tion situation for Emmeline - Pray
do - I will say no more
- Except on quite another
sort of subject - to congratu-
-late congratulate you and myself most
heartily, upon our dear
Fanny's restored health. -
You and Nature may
divide the prize - Take the
larger share to yourself - and
Nature will never be the worse
for it - And that you may
be the better I earnestly pray! -
